definitions: behave in a bold and shameless manner showing no respect for rules or others
examples: She brazened out the lie despite overwhelming evidence against her
The thief brazened his way past security with false confidence

definitions: make a gap in and break through a wall barrier or defense
fail to observe or act against a law agreement or code of conduct
examples: The flood waters breached the dam causing massive destruction downstream
Enemy forces breached the castle walls after weeks of siege
The company breached its contract by failing to deliver on time
His actions clearly breach the confidentiality agreement we all signed

definitions: swim using a stroke where arms push forward from chest while legs kick outward
examples: She prefers to breaststroke during her morning swim at the pool
The instructor taught beginners how to breaststroke before other swimming styles

definitions: mate animals to produce offspring especially for maintaining specific characteristics
cause something to happen or develop gradually over time
examples: They breed champion horses on their ranch in Kentucky
The farmer breeds cattle for their high quality meat production
Poverty and lack of education breed crime in urban areas
Success breeds confidence while failure breeds doubt and fear

definitions: make beer or tea by soaking boiling and fermenting ingredients
develop or gather force gradually like a storm or trouble
examples: He brews his own craft beer in the garage every weekend
Let the tea brew for five minutes before adding milk
A political scandal has been brewing for months in the capital
Dark clouds brew on the horizon signaling an approaching storm

definitions: dishonestly give money or gifts to someone to influence their actions or decisions
examples: The businessman tried to bribe the official with cash for permits
Parents shouldn't bribe their children with candy to behave properly

definitions: put a bridle on a horse to control its movements
react with anger or take offense at something perceived as criticism
examples: The rider bridled her horse before the morning trail ride
You need to bridle the stallion carefully as he's quite spirited
She bridled at his suggestion that her work needed improvement
He tends to bridle whenever someone questions his authority

definitions: organize people into groups for a specific purpose or coordinated action
examples: The volunteers were brigaded into teams to search the forest
The commander brigaded his troops according to their specialized skills

definitions: make or become lighter in color or more filled with light
make or become more cheerful optimistic or hopeful
examples: The morning sun brightened the dark room through the windows
Adding white paint will brighten these dull walls considerably
Her smile brightened when she saw her grandchildren arrive
The good news brightened everyone's mood after a difficult week

definitions: be full to the point of overflowing at the top edge
examples: Her eyes brimmed with tears during the emotional farewell speech
The cup brims with hot coffee threatening to spill over

definitions: soak food in salt water to preserve or add flavor before cooking
examples: She brines the turkey overnight before roasting it for Thanksgiving
The chef always brines pork chops to keep them moist and flavorful

definitions: walk or move in a quick energetic and active way
examples: They brisked along the trail trying to reach camp before dark
The manager brisked through the office checking on each department's progress

definitions: of hair or fur stand upright away from the skin
react in an angry or defensive way to something
examples: The cat's fur bristled when it saw the approaching dog
His beard bristled as he rubbed his chin in thought
She bristled at the unfair criticism of her performance
The senator bristled when reporters questioned his voting record

definitions: raise a difficult subject for discussion in a careful way
pierce a container to draw out its contents
examples: He finally broached the subject of marriage after dating for years
I don't know how to broach the topic of her poor performance
The sailors broached a new barrel of rum for the celebration
They broached the wine cask at the wedding feast

definitions: make or become wider in physical extent or range of knowledge experience
examples: Travel really broadens your understanding of different cultures and perspectives
The road broadens after the bridge to accommodate more traffic lanes

definitions: attack or collide with something from the side with full force
examples: The truck broadsided the car at the intersection causing serious damage
The storm broadsided the coastal town with unexpected intensity

definitions: arrange or negotiate a deal or agreement between different parties
examples: She brokered a peace agreement between the warring factions
The agent brokered the sale of the house for both parties

definitions: give something a brown color like bronze metal especially skin from sun
examples: The summer sun bronzed her skin during the beach vacation
Years of outdoor work had bronzed his face and arms

definitions: think deeply about something that makes you unhappy angry or worried
of a bird sit on eggs to keep them warm until they hatch
examples: He tends to brood over past mistakes instead of moving forward
She brooded about the argument for days unable to concentrate
The hen broods on her eggs for three weeks before they hatch
Wild geese brood their eggs in nests near the water

definitions: tolerate or allow something usually used in negative sentences
examples: The strict teacher brooks no nonsense in her classroom
He will not brook any interference with his plans

definitions: clean or clear an area by sweeping with a broom
examples: She brooms the porch every morning to keep it tidy
The janitor broomed the hallway after the students left

definitions: look through or read something in a casual relaxed way
of animals feed on leaves twigs or other plants
examples: She likes to browse through magazines while waiting at the dentist
I spent hours browsing the bookstore looking for something interesting
Deer browse on young shoots and leaves in the forest
The goats browse on bushes along the mountain path

definitions: injure body tissue causing discoloration without breaking the skin
damage or mark the surface of something slightly
examples: He bruised his knee badly when he fell off the bicycle
Be careful not to bruise your arm on that sharp corner
The apples bruised during transport and couldn't be sold
Don't squeeze the peaches or you'll bruise them

definitions: eat a meal that combines breakfast and lunch usually eaten late morning
examples: We love to brunch at that cafe every Sunday with friends
They brunched on pancakes and mimosas at the hotel restaurant

definitions: act as a pirate especially in the Caribbean during the 17th century
examples: Pirates would buccaneer throughout the Caribbean attacking merchant ships
The adventurers decided to buccaneer along the coast seeking treasure

definitions: fasten with a buckle by connecting a strap through a frame
bend or collapse under pressure strain or heat
examples: Please buckle your seatbelt before the plane takes off
She buckled her leather belt around her waist
His knees buckled under the heavy weight of the backpack
The metal beam buckled in the intense heat of the fire

definitions: of a plant produce buds as new growth begins to develop
examples: The roses are beginning to bud after the spring rain
Cherry trees bud early in the season before other fruit trees

definitions: move very slightly or give way to pressure
change an opinion or make someone change their position
examples: The heavy desk wouldn't budge even with three people pushing
The door was stuck and refused to budge
He won't budge on the price despite our negotiations
No amount of arguing could budge her from her decision

definitions: polish something by rubbing it with a soft cloth to make it shine
examples: He buffed his shoes until they gleamed like mirrors
The jeweler buffed the silver bracelet to restore its shine

definitions: intimidate or bewilder someone by being forceful confusing or misleading
examples: Don't let the salesman buffalo you into buying something unnecessary
The complex legal jargon was meant to buffalo the jury

definitions: lessen or moderate the impact of something harmful or reduce shock between forces
examples: The trees buffer our house from the highway noise
Savings can buffer you against unexpected financial emergencies

definitions: strike repeatedly and violently especially by wind or waves
examples: Strong winds buffeted the small plane during the storm
Waves buffeted the ship throughout the rough night at sea

definitions: play a bugle instrument or make a sound like a bugle
examples: The soldier bugled reveille at dawn to wake the troops
Elk bugle during mating season to attract females

definitions: swell or stick out in a rounded shape from pressure inside
examples: His pockets bulged with collected seashells from the beach
The bag bulged at the seams from being overpacked

definitions: increase in size weight or importance through growth or addition
buy or sell goods in large quantities for efficiency
examples: Athletes bulk up by eating more protein and lifting weights
The company bulked their inventory before the holiday season
Restaurants bulk buy ingredients to reduce costs per unit
We should bulk order office supplies to save money

definitions: attack or pursue something with determined persistence like a bulldog
examples: The detective bulldogged the case until he found the truth
She bulldogged her way through obstacles to achieve her goals

definitions: make an official public announcement or issue a bulletin about something
examples: The company bulletined the merger news to all employees
The weather service bulletined a severe storm warning

definitions: make something resistant to penetration by bullets or make very strong
examples: They bulletproofed the presidential car with special armor plating
We need to bulletproof our plan against potential criticism

definitions: use superior strength or influence to intimidate someone typically to force them to do something
examples: Older kids sometimes bully younger students for their lunch money
Don't let your boss bully you into working unpaid overtime

definitions: defend or protect something like a bulwark defensive wall
examples: The constitution bulwarks our fundamental rights from government overreach
Strong institutions bulwark democracy against authoritarian threats

definitions: get something by asking or begging from someone
spend time idly without purpose or direction
examples: He tried to bum a cigarette from passing strangers
Can I bum a ride to the store with you
They bummed around Europe for a summer after college
Stop bumming around and find something productive to do

definitions: move or act in an awkward or confused way making mistakes
examples: He bumbled through his presentation forgetting important points
The new employee bumbled around the office looking for supplies

definitions: hit or knock against something with a jolt or thud
move someone to a different level position or status
examples: She accidentally bumped the table spilling coffee everywhere
Cars bumped each other in the crowded parking lot
The airline bumped us to first class due to overbooking
He got bumped from the team after missing practice

definitions: tie or wrap things together into a compact group or package
examples: She bundled old newspapers for recycling every month
Bundle those cables together to keep the desk organized

definitions: throw put or push something somewhere in a careless or rough way
examples: Just bung those boxes in the garage for now
He bunged his clothes into the suitcase without folding

definitions: carry out a task clumsily or incompetently leading to failure or mistakes
examples: The thieves bungled the robbery and were caught immediately
Don't bungle this opportunity by being unprepared for the interview

definitions: sleep in a bunk bed or temporary sleeping place
skip school or work without permission
examples: The soldiers bunked in the barracks during basic training
We'll bunk at the hostel to save money on our trip
He decided to bunk class and go to the beach instead
Don't bunk work or you'll lose your job

definitions: in golf hit the ball into a sand bunker
store supplies or take shelter in a protective bunker
examples: He bunkered his shot on the ninth hole losing a stroke
Try not to bunker the ball near the green
The family bunkered supplies in their basement for emergencies
Soldiers bunkered down during the heavy artillery bombardment

definitions: in baseball tap the ball lightly with the bat instead of swinging
examples: The player bunted the ball down the third base line
She bunted successfully to advance the runner to second base

definitions: keep something afloat in water or maintain at a high level
make someone feel cheerful or confident
examples: Life jackets buoy swimmers in deep water for safety
Government spending buoyed the economy during the recession
The good news buoyed her spirits after a difficult week
His encouraging words buoyed the team's morale
